src:
Netanjahu: Ne kriviti protivnike mirovnog procesa za ubistvo Rabina

04 Nov 2019, 09:05

Premijer Izraela Benjamin Netanjahu ocenio je da političare i Izraelce koji su se protivili mirovnom sporazumu Oslo sa Palestincima ne bi trebalo smatrati odgovornim za ubistvo bivšeg premijera Jicaka Rabina."Onaj koji je odgovoran za užasno ubistvo premijera Jicaka Rabina je gnusni ubica Jigal Amir i šačica ekstremista", objavio je Netanjahu sinoć na Tviteru uoči 24-godišnjice Rabinove smrti, dodavši da su "bili i jesu zabranjeni pokušaji da se okrivi više od polovine nacije i lideri koji su se protivili sporazumu Oslo za taj zločin koji je počinio Jigal Amir".Rabina je 4. novembra 1995. godine ubio Amir, jevrejski ekstremista, koji se protivio sporazumu Oslo potpisanom u Beloj kući septembra 1993. godine i predaji kontrole nad delovima okupirane Zapadne obale Palestincima u okviru tog istorijskog sporazuma.Netanjahu je dugo optuživan da je igrao ulogu u huškanju protiv Rabina.On je te optužbe odbacivao, označivši ih kao "političko ubistvo".U nedeljama koje su prethodile Rabinovom ubistvu Netanjahu koji je tada bio vodja opozicije i drugi istaknuti članovi njegovog konzervativnog Likuda su prisustovali političkom mitingu u Jerusalimu na kojem su demonstranti Rabina nazivili "izdajnikom", "ubicom" i "nacistom" jer je potpisao mirovni sporazum sa Palestincima, podsećaju izraelski meidji.U subotu uveče desetine hiljada ljudi prisustvovale su u Tel Avivu obeležavanju godišnjice Rabinove smrti.Glavni Netanjahuov rival, mandatar za sastav nove izraelske vlade posle izbora 17. septembra, Beni Ganc, rekao je da će Izrael pobediti one koji mrze i nikada neće kapitulirati pred mržnjom.On je ocenio i da neki sadašnji političari ponovo seju mržnju i huškaju.Ganc, vodja saveza partija centra Plavo i belo, bio je glavni govornik na trgu u centralnom Tel Avivu.Taj trg sada nosi Rabinovo ime u čast premijera koji je tamo ubijen nakon što se obratio okupljenima na mitingu podrške mirovnim naporima svoje vlade.Ganc je rekao da je Rabin ubijen zbog podela, huškanja i mržnje, a da je "mržnja ponovo postala opasno oružje u rukama političara bez ograničenja".Iako se činilo da možda aludira na Netanjahua Ganc je ipak rekao da mržnja nije ograničena na odredjeni deo stanovništva niti političku grupu.
text:
Netanyahu: Not to blame opponents of the peace process for killing Rabin

04 Nov 2019, 09:05

Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu estimated that politicians and Israelis who opposed the Oslo peace treaty with the Palestinians should not be held responsible for the murder of former Prime Minister Jicak Rabin. " "Netanyahu tweeted last night on the eve of the 24th anniversary of Rabin's death, adding that" attempts to blame more than half of the nation and leaders opposed to the Oslo agreement on the crime committed by Jigal Amir were and are forbidden. " on November 4, 1995, killed Amir, a Jewish extremist, who opposed the Oslo agreement signed at the White House in September 1993 and surrendered control of parts of the occupied West Bank to Palestinians under that historic agreement. Netanyahu has long been accused of playing a role in He dismissed the allegations, labeling them "political murder". In the weeks before went to Rabin's assassination of Netanyahu, who was then leader of the opposition and other prominent members of his conservative Likud, attended a political rally in Jerusalem calling Rabbi's protesters "traitor," "killer" and "Nazi" because he signed a peace agreement with the Palestinians, Israeli recalls meidji.On Saturday night, tens of thousands of people attended Tel Aviv to commemorate the anniversary of Rabin's death.Netanyahu's chief rival, the new Israeli government's post-September 17 constituency, Benny Ganz, said Israel would defeat those who hate and never capitulate He also estimated that some current politicians are sowing hate and incitement again. Ganz, leader of the Blue and White Center Party Alliance, was the keynote speaker in Central Tel Aviv Square.This square now bears Rabin's name in honor of the prime minister who is there killed after addressing a rally in support of his government's peacekeeping rally.Ganc said the rabbi was killed because of division, incitement and hatred, with "hatred becoming a dangerous weapon again in the hands of politicians without restriction." It seemed that he might be alluding to Netanyahu Ganz, however, said that hatred was not limited to a particular population or political group.
